{{Geobox|Range | name=MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains | native_name= | image= | image_caption= | image_flag= | map=Antarctica,_Norway_territorial_claim.svg | map_caption=Map depicting the territorial extent of Queen Maud Land | region=[[Queen Maud Land]], [[East Antarctica]] | region_type = | country=Antarctica | country_type=Continent | country_flag=true | parent=[[East Antarctica Ranges]] | border= | geology= | period= | orogeny= | highest=[[Kyrkjeskipet Peak]] | highest_elevation_imperial=10121 | highest_lat_d=72|highest_lat_m=00|highest_lat_s=00|highest_lat_NS=S | highest_long_d=05|highest_long_m=20|highest_long_s=00|highest_long_EW=E }} The '''MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains''' is a major group of associated [[mountain]] features extending east to west for 65 miles between the [[Gjelsvik Mountains]] and the [[Orvin Mountains]] in [[Queen Maud Land]], [[East Antarctica]]. With its [[Summit (topography)|summit]] at {{convert|3085|m|ft|0}}, the massive [[Kyrkjeskipet Peak]] forms the highest point in the MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains.
==Discovery and naming== {{Location map|Antarctica|lat_deg=72|lat_min=00|lat_dir=S|lon_deg=05|lon_min=20|lon_dir=E|float=left|mark=Fire.svg|marksize=12|AlternativeMap=Antarctica relief location map.jpg|label=MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains|position=top|caption=Map depicting the location of the MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains in [[Queen Maud Land]], [[Antarctica]]}}
The MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains were discovered by the [[Third German Antarctic Expedition]] (1938-1939), led by Capt. [[Alfred Ritscher]], and named for the division director of the [[German Air Ministry]]. They were remapped by the [[Sixth Norwegian Antarctic Expedition|Norwegian Antarctic Expedition]], 1956-1960.<ref>[http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/ USGS GNIS: MÃ¼hlig-Hofmann Mountains]</ref>
